questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following statements is false about non-invasive prenatal testing?

options.a: It uses cell-free circulating fetal DNA in the maternal serum
options.b: It is used for the diagnosis of trisomy 13, 18 and 21
options.c: It can be performed after 10 weeks of gestation
options.d: It is done after the routine first trimester ultrasound assessment

questions.explanation:
Non-invasive prenatal testing (NIPT) is used for the screening of trisomy 13, 18 and 21 and 
Turner's syndrome. It is not a diagnostic test. It is a novel genetic test that uses cell-free circulating fetal DNA in the maternal serum for 
screening of chromosomal anomalies. DNA from the fetus is found circulating in the maternal blood in two forms - either inside the 
intact fetal cells or as cell-free DNA from the breakdown of placental fetal cells. In NIPT, the 
cell-free chromosome fragments are measured and the quantitative differences from normal 
fetuses are noted. NIPT can be performed after 10 weeks of gestation and is recommended after the routine 
first-trimester ultrasound assessment in high-risk pregnancies or if either 1st or 2nd-trimester 
screening becomes positive. Its disadvantage is that it is very expensive and it can be used for 
screening of only a few chromosomal anomalies such as trisomy 13, 18, and 21 and it doesn't 
analyse the entire karyotype.

questions.question:
Question 2: A pregnant woman has a fetus with Down's syndrome. Triple test done at 15-16 weeks will 
have  
.

options.a: Low MSAFP, high hCG, low UE3
options.b: High MSAFP, low hCG, high UE3
options.c: Low MSAFP, high hCG, high UE3
options.d: High MSAFP, low hCG, low UE3

questions.explanation:
The triple test findings in pregnancies with fetal Down’s syndrome are characterized by: • Low MSAFP (maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein) levels, approximately 0.7 MoM (multiples of 
median). • Low unconjugated estriol levels, approximately 0.8 MoM. • High hCG levels, approximately 2.0 MoM. The triple test is done between 15-18 weeks for the diagnosis of Down's syndrome. 150 
Sold by @itachibot Various antenatal screening tests for aneuploidy are as follows: First-trimester screening with biochemical analytes () PAPP-A and () hCG and USG 
measurement of NT () can improve the detection rate (87%) of Down’s syndrome. For 
confirmation, a prenatal genetic study (CVS, amniocentesis or cordo■centesis) has to be 
performed. Second-trimester screening (quad screening) at 15–18 weeks: () MSAFP, () uE3, () inhibin A 
and () hCG can detect trisomy 21 in 85% of cases with a false-positive rate of 0.9%. When it is 
combined with first-trimester screening, the detection rate is increased to 95%. Dual test (1sttrimester) 
Triple test (2ndtrimester)

questions.question: Question 3: Which of the following is not included in the quadruple screening test?
questions.explanation:
Inhibin B is not a component assayed under the quad-screening test. Dimeric inhibin-A is 
evaluated in this screening test. ‘uadruple testing is done in the second trimester between 15-21 weeks of gestation. It comprises: • Maternal serum AFP • Human chorionic gonadotropin • Unconjugated estriol (E3) • Dimeric inhibin A The following table summarizes the findings of the quad-screening test in various conditions. questions.question: Question 4: ‘uadruple testing is done during:
questions.explanation:
The quadruple screening test is ideally done in the second trimester, during 15-20 weeks of 
gestation. The most accurate values are seen during 16-18 weeks of gestation. It is the measurement of maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein (MSAFP), unconjugated estriol, hCG, 
and inhibin-A. In Down's syndrome (trisomy 21) or Edward's syndrome (trisomy 18), quadruple-marker 
screenings do not provide any added benefit over first-trimester screenings. It is generally used as 
a stand-alone test if screening is done for the first time in the second trimester or if first-trimester 
screening is not available. Neural tube defect or abdomi

questions.question: Question 6: In which of the following conditions is an increased level of alpha fetoprotein seen?
questions.explanation:
In underestimated gestational age, there is an increased level of maternal serum alpha fetoprotein 
(MSAFP). Elevated levels of MSAFP are seen in: • Underestimated gestational age • Severe oligohydramnios • Multifetal pregnancy • Neural tube defects • Abdominal wall defects- Omphalocele, Gastroschisis • Hepatoma • Endodermal sinus tumour Reduced levels of MSAFP are seen in: • Overestimated gestational age • Overweight mother • Gestational trophoblastic diseases • Spontaneous abortion • Trisomy 18 and 21

questions.question:
Question 7: Increased maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein is detected in a primigravida. What is the next 
step in management?

options.a: Repeat measurement of MSAFP at a later date

questions.explanation:
The next best step is targeted sonography. Maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein (MSAFP) levels are 
only used as a screening test and must be followed by a diagnostic test. Amniocentesis is a diagnostic test for amniotic fluid AFP measurement. It was once considered 
the standard for the diagnosis of open neural tube disorders but has been replaced in most centers 
by targeted sonography. Defects in fetal integuments, such as ventral wall and neural tube defects, permit fetal AFP to leak 
into the amnionic fluid. This results in increased MSAFP levels. This is detected on screening 
performed from 15 to 20 weeks of gestation. 153 
Sold by @itachibot Conditions with elevated MSAFP: • Wrong gestational age • Neural tube defects • Multiple pregnancies • Renal anomalies Conditions with decreased MSAFP: • Trisomies (Down's syndrome) • Gestational trophoblastic disease.

questions.question: Question 8: Which of the following statements is true regarding alpha fetoprotein?

options.a: MSAFP is detected at 16-18 weeks of gestation
options.b: Diabetic patients have increased AFP levels
options.c: MSAFP is unrelated to period of gestation
options.d: Lowest fetal AFP is seen around 13 weeks of gestation

questions.explanation:
The maternal serum AFP screening is generally performed from 15-20 weeks of gestation. Hence, 
it is detected in this period. Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) is the major serum protein in the embryo and fetus. It is produced by the 
yolk sac and fetal liver. Option B: Diabetic patients have low levels of AFP. Option C: Gestational age influences the MSAFP levels. The maternal serum concentration 
increases by approximately 15% per week during the second trimester. Option D: At about 13 weeks of gestation, the AFP concentration in the fetal serum and amniotic 
fluid are highest, after which it declines. Conversely, AFP is found in steadily increasing quantities 
in maternal serum after 12 weeks.

questions.question:
Question 9: During genetic counseling, a pregnant woman states that both she and her husband have 
sickle cell trait. You offer the option of chorionic villus sampling for prenatal diagnosis. What 
is the best time to perform this procedure?
questions.explanation:
The best time to perform chorionic villous sampling is 11-13 weeks. Chorionic villus sampling: Study material

questions.question:
Question 11: A 28-year-old woman presents with 6 weeks of amenorrhea and a positive urine pregnancy 
test. She states her brother had cystic fibrosis and asks if her child might have the same. 
Which of the following methods would not be useful for prenatal diagnosis of this condition?
questions.explanation:
Fetal skin biopsy is not a recommended method of prenatal diagnosis of cystic fibrosis. It is done 
to detect inherited skin conditions such as: • Ichthyosis 155 
Sold by @itachibot • Epidermolysis bullosa • Oculocutaneous albinism Invasive procedures for prenatal diagnosis of CFTR gene mutations in cystic fibrosis include: • Chorionic villus sampling (CVS) • Amniocentesis • Cordocentesis or percutaneous umbilical blood sampling (PUBS)

questions.question:
Question 12: 147 
Sold by @itachibot A G2P1 woman at 35 weeks of pregnancy presents with complaints of decreased fetal 
movement. What is the next step in management?
questions.explanation:
In case of reduced fetal movements, the first step of management is to do a non-stress test (NST). Interpretation of NST: • Reactive • 2 accelerations of >15 beats/minute above the baseline and longer than 15 seconds in 
duration are present in a 20-minute observation • Reassure the patient and send back home • Non-reactive - biophysical profile (BPP) has to be assessed.

questions.question: Question 13: The CTG shown in the image below may be seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.explanation: The given CTG shows early deceleration which is seen in cases of head compression.

questions.question:
Question 14: A 35-year-old G2P1 at 38 weeks of gestation came to the labor room with complaints of 
decreased fetal movements. Non-stress test was done and late decelerations were noted. What 
does this indicate?
questions.explanation:
The given scenario is suggestive of fetal hypoxia. Late decelerations are seen on an NST in this 
condition. Deceleration is a decrease in fetal heart rate below the baseline by 15 bpm for more than 15 
seconds. Absent variability of FHR with late decelerations is an indication for immediate Cesarean 
section. 156 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 15: A pregnant woman brings her son to the hospital for routine immunization. While awaiting 
his turn, she realizes that her seat is stained with blood. She is rushed to the nearby antenatal 
clinic. Pulse - 96/min, BP - 110/80 mmHg. Vaginal bleeding is noted and her NST is shown 
below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario along with the NST showing a sinusoidal pattern point towards a 
diagnosis of vasa previa. Vasa previa is a condition where fetal vessels travel within the membranes and overlie the cervical 
os. Hence, there can be bleeding during cervical dilatation or membrane rupture. Fetal mortality is high due to fetal exsanguination. When bleeding is present in vasa previa, 
an emergency cesarean section is indicated. Causes of sinusoidal pattern on NST include: • Severe fetal anemia - Rh isoimmunisation, vasa previa, fetomaternal hemorrhage, or twin to 
twin transfusion • Opioids - meperidine, morphine, alphaprodine, butorphanol • Amnionitis • Fetal distress • Umbilical cord occlusion. 157 
Sold by @itachibot 158 
Sold by @itachibot Obstetrical Imaging
